header.title: The Watcher (Issue No.2, April/May/June 1990CE)
header.category: Satanism, Esotericism, Occultism, Left-Hand Path, Periodical

central_thesis: The newsletter's central thesis, primarily articulated in the 'Satanism & Morality' article, is that popular perceptions of Satanism are 'spurious Christian concoctions' devoid of genuine Satanic principles. True Satanism, as espoused by the Order of the Left-Hand Path, is presented as a 'morality of the strong' rooted in the 'godhood of man,' emphasizing indulgence of natural drives (distinct from self-destruction), pride, wisdom, and individuality, in stark contrast to perceived Christian nihilism and the dissipation of pseudo-Satanists.

structure_content.summary: Critiques the common association of 'Satanism' with heavy metal, drugs, and anti-social behavior, labeling it a 'spurious Christian concoction' used for rebellion. It contrasts this with 'genuine Satanism,' which is presented as a 'morality of the strong' based on the 'godhood of man,' advocating for the indulgence of natural drives and virtues like pride, wisdom, and individuality, while explicitly rejecting self-abuse (e.g., drug/alcohol addiction) as antithetical to Satanic self-discipline and strength.

Expounds on the moral framework of genuine Satanism, defining it by the concept of 'ego as godhood' and the Satanist as the 'highest embodiment of human life,' drawing from LaVey and Nietzsche. It clarifies the 'indulgence' principle from the Nine Satanic Statements as the gratification of instinctive primary and physiological drives for physical, mental, or emotional satisfaction, while unequivocally distinguishing this from 'pandering of every whim and weakness' or self-destructive behaviors like addiction, which are seen as undermining the will and the pursuit of 'godhood.'

structure_content.chapter_title: BOOK REVIEW: SOCIAL REALISM & THE SECOND COMING
structure_content.summary: Reviews Rev. Yaj Nomolos's book on 'Social Realism,' a Satanic doctrine termed 'Survival And The Androgyne Nation.' Nomolos characterizes Satanism as a 'predator's doctrine' and predicts a future cataclysm where 'Chosen Ones' of Homo Sapiens will evolve into an Androgyne species via conscious mental mutation. It critiques the 'Necrophilic Phallocratic, Patriarchal Process' (Religion, Government, Business) and outlines the role of Social Realists in preparing for this new species.

Reports on a new Christian sect, the Protestant Bible Believers Church, which adopts a literal, harsh interpretation of biblical teachings (e.g., eternal damnation, disowning family for discipleship), contrasting them with 'watered-down' mainstream churches. Also includes an expos√© titled 'BUGGERING UP THE CATHOLIC CHURCH,' detailing historical and contemporary instances of sexual misconduct among Catholic clergy, citing specific Popes and modern statistics on child sexual abuse cases.

Lists esoteric and Satanic texts available for purchase, including 'Essays on Satanism' and 'Anti-Christ: The Bible Reconsidered' by Faustus Scorpius, 'The Book of The Law' by Aleister Crowley, 'Might Is Right' by Ragnar Redbeard, and 'Rites of Satan,' a compilation of various rituals.

Describes a comprehensive course offered by the Order of the Left-Hand Path (OLHP) covering the fundamentals of Satanism, based on OLHP texts. The course includes questions, essays, and practical exercises. Successful completion and signing an affirmation of Satanic allegiance lead to a 'certificate of ordination into the Satanic Priesthood.'

key_concepts.definition: A philosophical and moral framework, distinct from popular misconceptions, advocating for the 'godhood of man,' indulgence of natural drives (without self-destruction), pride, wisdom, individuality, self-control, and physical well-being. It is a 'morality of the strong' informed by LaVeyan and Nietzschean principles.

The popular, erroneous conception of Satanism, often associated with heavy metal culture, drug abuse, alcoholism, death worship, and anti-social behavior. It is viewed as a 'spurious Christian concoction' used by disillusioned youth for rebellion against mainstream Christianity.

The cardinal premise of Satanism, where man is seen as having potential for godhood and strives to 'go beyond himself' in a Nietzschean sense. This involves developing will-power, self-discipline, and strength.

A Satanic moral outlook that emphasizes strength of body, mind, and will, pride, wisdom, and individuality. It confronts the 'trivialization of life, mass-tastes, herd-conformity' of the modern world and is foundational to the Satanist becoming the 'highest embodiment of human life.'

A core tenet (from LaVey's Nine Satanic Statements) advocating the indulgence of instinctive primary and physiological drives (hunger, thirst, sex, sleep, stimulation, exploration, etc.) for gratification, in contrast to Christian repression. Crucially, this is distinguished from self-abuse, self-dissipation, or pandering to weakness.

A concept from Rev. Yaj Nomolos's 'Social Realism' Satanism, envisioning a future species that evolves from 'Chosen Ones' of Homo Sapiens through conscious mental mutation, combining both male and female into a single biological entity as a means of survival and adaptation to cataclysmic environmental changes.

An ordained status granted by the Order of the Left-Hand Path (OLHP) upon successful completion of their Correspondence Course in Satanism and affirmation of Satanic allegiance, signifying a formal leadership or authoritative role within the OLHP tradition.

practical_system.description: The Order of the Left-Hand Path (OLHP) offers a structured system rooted in philosophical and moral development, heavily drawing from LaVeyan Satanism and Nietzschean concepts. This system emphasizes the 'godhood of man,' self-control, strength, and individuality, aiming to cultivate 'the highest embodiment of human life.' The primary practical mechanism for engagement and advancement is a formal 'Correspondence Course in Satanism,' which serves as an educational pathway leading to eventual ordination into the Satanic Priesthood, providing a structured means for adherence, learning, and leadership within the OLHP tradition.

relevant_quotes.text: 'My friends are into evil spirits and messing with Satanism. The boy who is the leader of this is a good friend. He is into heavy metal and has satanic symbols on his bedroom wall. He is leading my friends astray. ... My friends have started drugs and drinking. ... I ask for prayer to give me strength with God to get them out of this mess, before it's too late.'

Contrary to Christian hysteria, the predominant negative influence impacting upon the youths mentioned in the above-quoted letter, and thousands of other throughout the Western world, is not genuine Satanism. It is rather, a spurious Christian concoction which they have turned to as a rejection of the repression, hypocrisy and unreality of Christianity, which has failed to give them a positive lead.

Since the cardinal point of Satanism is the godhood of man, or more precisely, the potential godhood towards which the outstanding individual strives above the mass - to 'go beyond himself' in a Nietzschean sense - this implies a strong moral outlook, which we may better term a 'morality of the strong.'

The first of the Nine Satanic Statements declares: "Satan represents indulgence, instead of abstinence!" This must surely mean indulgence of the instinctive primary and physiological drives, and stimulus motives...

Addiction to, or excessive use of, tobacco, alcohol or drugs is not satisfaction of the primary drives and stimulus motives which lead to health, but a means of self-abuse, self-dissipation, and self-destruction, and therefore a contradiction of natural law...
"Satanism is a predator's doctrine, a doctrine to inspire the strong and cut the heart out of the weak."

Pride, Wisdom, Individuality, are three basics upon which a 'Satanic morality' can be constructed, a life-affirming morality which confronts the values of the present day, with their trivilization of life, mass-tastes, herd-conformity.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of 'The Watcher' is highly relevant for understanding the self-definition and polemical strategies of a specific Left-Hand Path group (Order of the Left-Hand Path) in the late 20th century. It offers a clear articulation of how LaVeyan and Nietzschean philosophies were integrated to differentiate 'genuine Satanism' from popular, often Christian-influenced, misconceptions. It provides insight into the intellectual and moral arguments employed to attract adherents and critique both mainstream Christianity and 'pseudo-Satanic' subcultures. The inclusion of the 'Social Realism' review further contextualizes the broader landscape of esoteric thought within the Left-Hand Path at the time.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is primarily individuals interested in or exploring Satanism, the Left-Hand Path, and alternative philosophies, particularly those disillusioned with mainstream Christianity or seeking a structured, self-empowering spiritual and moral framework. It also appeals to existing practitioners and scholars within these traditions, providing intellectual discourse, educational resources (like the correspondence course), and curated occult materials. The confrontational and critical tone suggests an audience that appreciates a rigorous, anti-dogmatic, and often anti-Christian stance.
